review_title: Ambitious charity with supportive ethos and flexible culture
pros: Centrepoint has come a long way in the 3+ years I have worked here. The work culture has massively improved, and within the fundraising department the Director has built a very supportive team who are genuinely the most talented fundraisers I have worked with. I don't think there is space for weak links at CP, you do work hard and at times the workload can be challenging but this ebbs and flows throughout the year. The impact of your work can really be seen and the hard work pays off when you see how it really helps young people in need. If you demonstrate yourself then you will be rewarded with a good work/life balance, and I do think Centrepoint are strong in this field. Particularly if there is a lack of progression route, they will try to benefit you in other ways. A lot of work has been undertaken in the last 2 years to improve the culture and benefits, from visible inclusion initiatives to really excellent health benefits such as Medicash/BUPA that tangibly help and are rare in the charity sector. The HR team are supportive and receptive to feedback. The majority of colleagues are very willing to help when you need it, and it generally feels like a supportive workplace. All in all, it feels like a safe and supportive workplace that also accepts that you have a life outside of work - HR and my line manager have been very supportive around a challenging change in my health over the last year and ensuring I have the adaptations I require to be able to carry on succeeding in my role. While there have been a couple of blips in the last years, these have always been effectively handled by senior members in the team and/or HR when required. Centrepoint is a pragmatic workplace, no organisation is perfect but they really are trying to improve things as best as they can and I really can see the effects of this compared to when I started. I think it's a great charity to be part of.
cons: - Departments can feel silo'ed at times - Progression routes are not always there - Some senior management changes needed - a mixed bag

review_title: Could have real potential , but probably too late
pros:
- Met a handful of great colleagues in the short time I was there .
-There are some genuinely motivated young people who do want your support and welcome it , however there are also a lot of staff who make excuses for certain behaviour of young people and to an extent are setting them up to fail . 
- Some good in house and external training opportunities 
- Great contacts with external providers who are open to offering time , money , training etc
- Salary was 'okay'
cons:
*I can only comment on MY experience , however this isn't an isolated case and have since spoken to existing and previous colleagues who encountered similar things .
- Sheer lack of professionalism from some managers , this included talking down to staff , lording over staff , using their status to try and intimidate colleagues , lack of empathy or real drive to actually get to know their employees . 
- The charity isn't as it seems on the adds , appeals etc . Great Marketing team for sure but if you're looking to join a charity / organisation whereby you can make a real difference then its unlikely CP is the place to do that .
- Lack of professionalism amongst colleagues , speaking down to one another in front of young people , undermining one anothers work publicly , lack of accountability . 
- Not taking on board skills and experience that you may have been able to bring to the role ( despite the fact this is what secured you the role in the first instance ) .
- Fear of treading on colleagues toes rather than working collaboratively .
- Rather than empowering young people , there is this toxicity whereby staff can use young peoples challenges as a direct barrier for them which in turn leaves you working with a lot of 'entitled young people ' . 
- High staff turnover , poor documentation of contact with a young person ( probably due to high turnover and use of agency staff ) . 
- Some great provisions put in place but not supported by the wider teams therefore young people are not interested in engaging .
